content.summary: Options ranked by time-to-learning for Telechy UI improvements over OpenCode's web app

data.problem: OpenCode's web app lacks visual branching/forking capabilities. Fork functionality exists in backend and TUI but web app displays conversations linearly. Users can't visualize conversation trees, navigate between branches, or fork from the web interface.
constraints: OpenCode backend already supports forking (session.fork API exists)
Sessions have parentID field for tree relationships
Web app is SolidJS (Telechy is React - no direct port)
Fork creates NEW session, not inline branch

options.name: Linear-first with Fork Button
options.approach: Add simple fork button to Telechy's existing linear UI. When clicked, fork creates new session and shows toast with link. Keep familiar linear flow, add escape hatch.
options.what_we_learn: Whether users actually need visual branching or just want fork capability. Test simplest implementation first.
options.risk_if_wrong: Low - minimal code, easy to extend later

options.name: Session Tabs with Fork
options.approach: Add tab bar showing related sessions (parent + children). Fork creates new tab. Like browser tabs - flat but shows relationships. Use session.parentID to group.
options.what_we_learn: Whether tab metaphor works for conversation branches. Familiar UI pattern, low cognitive load.
options.risk_if_wrong: Medium - more UI work but uses proven pattern

options.name: Branching Timeline Component
options.approach: Replace linear message rail with visual tree showing branch points. Click to navigate. Like git branch visualization but for conversations.
options.what_we_learn: Full branching UX - does visual tree help or confuse? Can we make it intuitive?
options.risk_if_wrong: High - significant investment, may not match mental models

options.name: Side-by-Side Branch Comparison
options.approach: After forking, show two panels with original and forked branch. Diff-style comparison of conversation paths.
options.what_we_learn: Whether comparison view is valuable. Heavy UI investment.
options.risk_if_wrong: High - complex UX, may be overkill for most use cases

data.recommendation: Option 1 (Linear-first with Fork Button) because it validates the core hypothesis (do users want forking?) with minimal investment. OpenCode already has the fork API - we just need a button. If users actually use fork, Option 2 (Session Tabs) is the natural next step. The visual tree (Option 3) is a larger bet that should wait until we confirm forking is valuable.
